channel.title: WITH GOD DAILY - Audio Devotional
channel.description: Daily audio devotional from Skye Jethani, automatically updated each morning.
channel.itunes:author: Skye Jethani

item.title: Ps 12: A Lesson in Gravity
item.description: This devotional, drawing from Psalm 12, contrasts the insecure boasting and manipulative words of those lacking spiritual depth with the profound "gravity of soul" possessed by God and the righteous. True power, exemplified by Jesus' humble birth, stems from an authentic, weighty presence rooted in truth, which naturally influences others without needing theatrics or exaggeration.

item.title: Ps 23: The Good Shepherd Arrives
item.description: This devotional explains how the familiar image of God as a good shepherd, found in Psalm 23, finds its ultimate fulfillment in Jesus. Old Testament prophecies foretold a righteous king, the "Good Shepherd," who would rescue God's lost and straying people from neglect and sin. Jesus' birth, announced to shepherds, declared him to be this long-awaited divine Shepherd, who came to lay down his life for his sheep.

item.title: Ps 22: Never Abandoned by God
item.description: This devotional explores Psalm 22 and Jesus' cry of abandonment on the cross, validating the universal human experience of questioning God's goodness and intervention during suffering. However, it ultimately affirms that God has not truly abandoned or hidden His face from the afflicted, but hears and cares, a truth powerfully demonstrated by the birth of Jesus at Christmas.

item.title: Ps 21: Praising Power
item.description: This devotional explains that psalms praising a king's power, like Psalm 21, are best understood as messianic prophecies, referring to Jesus Christ. Unlike corrupt human rulers, Jesus is the incorruptible King who will wield power righteously to establish God's rule. Therefore, we can trust and celebrate His coming as a leader beyond reproach.

item.title: Ps 19: Ruler of Creation
item.description: This devotional highlights that creation actively affirms God's glory and Jesus' identity, from His birth to His death, serving as more than just a backdrop. Jesus, the "second Adam," came to perfectly fulfill humanity's original calling to rule over creation in communion with God, a dominion the first Adam forfeited. Through His life and power, Jesus demonstrated this intended dominion, repairing the chaos of sin and revealing God's character within creation itself.

item.title: Learning to Live with God Right Where You Are
item.description: This devotional challenges the common misconception that fulfilling Christ's mission demands changing one's life circumstances or dedicating oneself solely to "sacred" church work. Instead, it emphasizes that God's expansive kingdom mission is lived out by welcoming heaven into our everyday vocations, relationships, and ordinary lives, right where we are. True discipleship means manifesting God's kingdom within our current circumstances, rather than abandoning them.

item.title: Beware of Vampire Churches
item.description: This devotional warns against "vampire churches" that drain members' spiritual life by treating them as resources for institutional goals, rather than empowering them for their broader callings. A healthy church, conversely, equips believers to deepen their relationship with God and manifest Christ's kingdom through their vocations and daily lives, fostering peace and joy. It's crucial to discern if a church cultivates true spiritual maturity and widespread impact, or simply consumes its members.

item.title: How Big is God?s Mission?
item.description: Daily devotional for Dec 17, 2025

item.title: A Pyramid Without a Product
item.description: This devotional warns that many churches, in their effort to "make disciples who make disciples," risk becoming like a "pyramid without a product" by failing to define what a true disciple is. This results in a self-perpetuating system that lacks spiritual substance, analogous to an illegal pyramid scheme. Such an approach, focused solely on growth without a clear "product," ultimately harms individuals and endangers the church's true mission.

item.title: A Place to Wrestle
item.description: This devotional explains that Christian faith involves a continuous "wrestling with God" over profound questions of meaning and purpose, acknowledging that doubt is inherent to the journey. Like Jacob, believers grapple with fear and uncertainty, but learn to trust God even when His plan isn't clear. The church provides a vital community where this spiritual struggle is shared, offering comfort and reaffirmation that God's justice ultimately prevails.

item.title: The Essential Church
item.description: A study found that personal spiritual disciplines, meaningful relationships, and serving others foster faith more than elaborate church programs or buildings. This calls the church to rethink its identity, shifting from a programmatic institution to a Spirit-driven, relational community essential for individual spiritual formation and God's mission in the world.

item.title: Character or Charisma?
item.description: This devotional argues that much of American Christianity, influenced by an "Evangelical Industrial Complex," has strayed from biblical standards by prioritizing marketplace acumen and charisma over spiritual maturity and character in its leaders. Consequently, leaders are often selected for their ability to generate revenue rather than their capacity to genuinely shepherd the flock, leaving believers vulnerable to ungodly influence and the dangers of a business-driven faith.

item.title: The Peril of Visionary Churches
item.description: This devotional critiques the modern church's business-influenced concept of "vision" as a leader's strategic plan, explaining that biblical "vision" refers instead to God's divine revelation. Adopting the worldly definition dangerously elevates human leaders and their ideas above Christ, who alone is the true spiritual unifier of a Christian community.

item.title: The Problem With ?You?
item.description: This devotional emphasizes that many New Testament letters were written to "us" (the church) rather than just "me," despite modern English translations using a singular "you." Our cultural individualism often leads us to misinterpret these communal instructions as solely personal commands, misapplying scripture and overlooking our corporate identity in Christ. Therefore, we must consciously consider how biblical teachings apply to our community, not just ourselves, to truly understand and live out our faith.

item.title: Best of Enemies
item.description: This devotional cautions against the cultural tendency, even among Christians, to define ourselves and our faith through anger, contempt, and the demonization of "enemies." It asserts that true Christian faith, exemplified by the early church, should instead be motivated by Christ's unifying love and the cross, where Jesus sacrificed himself for his adversaries. Believers are called to release hatred and find their definition in God's love, not in division or animosity.

item.title: Enemies No More
item.description: Amidst deep societal division, this devotional emphasizes that a true Christian community is defined by its ability to reconcile former enemies and reflect God's unity. The spiritual key to achieving this is actively praying for the blessing and well-being of our opponents, a transformative practice that heals our own hearts, fosters reconciliation, and serves as the church's most powerful weapon against evil.

item.title: The Middle Voice
item.description: Many Christians experience disillusionment because faith, when practiced as either relentless activity or passive waiting, often fails to transform lives. The devotional argues that true spiritual transformation occurs in the "middle voice," a collaborative and communal process where individuals, the church, and God actively participate and act upon one another. This relational and cooperative approach fosters genuine growth and heart change within a supportive community.

item.title: The Jesus Bus
item.description: This devotional challenges the idea of church leaders assembling a "bus" of the "right people," reminding us that the church belongs to Jesus. He intentionally brings together diverse individuals, even those with opposing views, demonstrating that true spiritual unity comes solely from abiding in Him, not from shared backgrounds, politics, or values. Therefore, Christians must examine if they are trying to dictate who belongs, or if they are truly on Jesus' inclusive bus.

item.title: Pure Thanksgiving
item.description: This devotional challenges believers to examine their motives for gratitude, distinguishing between manipulative thanksgiving offered with an ulterior motive for future blessings and a purer form. It argues that true gratitude, exemplified by the one leper who returned to Jesus, seeks nothing in return and focuses on the Divine Giver himself, rather than merely the gifts received. Christians are thus encouraged to cultivate a selfless appreciation for God, the ultimate Source of all blessings.

item.title: 11:00 Sunday Morning
item.description: The devotional challenges the church for often reflecting and reinforcing societal divisions through its racial homogeneity, rather than courageously overcoming them. It contrasts this with Jesus, who intentionally united a diverse group of disciples?like a Zealot and a tax collector?solely through their shared faith in Him, prioritizing this beautiful unity over pragmatism. Therefore, the church must embrace such Christ-centered diversity within its own walls if it hopes to play any role in healing the divisions of the world.

item.title: The Uncritical Currents of Culture
item.description: The church's fundamental purpose is to preview God's kingdom by actively transcending and healing societal divisions, uniting diverse people into a new household of faith, rather than reinforcing worldly customs. Christians are called to intentionally examine their cultural values and practices, ensuring they embody Christ's vision of a unified community rather than unknowingly betraying it by perpetuating divisions.

item.title: An Unworldly Strength
item.description: This devotional contrasts Jesus' unworldly strength, forged in prayer and manifesting as love even for his enemies, with the world's fearful, combative power. It challenges the modern church, often operating out of fear with worldly weapons, to instead emulate Christ. Through prayer, the church can transform its fear into faith and anger into love, accessing divine strength to reflect Jesus' character.

item.title: The Church Finds a Way
item.description: Daily devotional for Nov 18, 2025

item.title: Master Slave
item.description: Daily devotional for Nov 17, 2025

item.title: The Intent Behind the Instruments
item.description: This devotional highlights that true Christian worship, as exemplified by King David, transcends external rituals, music, or temples. God primarily desires a broken spirit and a contrite heart?a genuine relationship?rather than mere performance or mechanical offerings. External acts of worship are only meaningful when they express this deeper desire for God's heart.

item.title: An Oasis of Beauty
item.description: Daily devotional for Nov 13, 2025

item.title: Worship, Beauty, Justice
item.description: This devotional argues that a consumerist, utilitarian mindset often infects Christian worship, leading us to see God and people as valuable only if useful or transactional. Instead, true worship should embrace beauty and "impracticality" to counteract this impulse and remind us that God and all humanity are to be adored. This adoration, expressed through valuing what isn't useful, is the essential prelude to pursuing justice for the oppressed and neglected.

item.title: Beautiful Worship
item.description: This devotional highlights the difference between transactional and genuine worship, using the example of the woman anointing Jesus. It teaches that true Christian worship is an impractical, beautiful act of adoration, motivated by love for God's intrinsic worth rather than practical utility or personal gain. Genuine worship flows from a heart captivated by God's beauty, pouring out our highest value as a pure expression of devotion.

item.title: Don?t Worship Like a Pagan
item.description: This devotional contrasts pagan mythologies, where humans serve gods out of necessity, with the biblical truth that God is self-sufficient and does not *need* our worship or offerings. It argues that viewing worship as a transaction?offering praise to receive blessings?is a pagan mindset, not true Christianity. Instead, proper Christian worship is a non-transactional act of adoring God as an end in Himself, finding spiritual fulfillment in simply gazing upon His beauty and discovering His reciprocal adoration for us.

item.title: A Nonsensical Gesture of Love
item.description: This devotional argues that authentic Christian worship is a "nonsensical gesture of love," spontaneously offered to God from an encounter with His holiness, rather than a pragmatic calculation of personal gain or institutional growth. It challenges modern tendencies to approach worship with marketplace metrics, urging believers to embrace a selfless delight in God that transcends utility and feedback.

item.title: Ground Control, We Have a Problem
item.description: Drawing from the experience of astronauts who needed to pause for cosmic reflection, this devotional emphasizes that Christians require intentional rest and meditation, particularly through Sunday worship. This practice allows us to gain God's perspective on our lives and work, fostering spiritual renewal and communion rather than solely focusing on relentless activity. Ultimately, it calls for a rhythm of mission and meditation to maintain a proper perspective on ourselves, our calling, and our Lord.

item.title: No Rest for the Weary
item.description: This devotional emphasizes the spiritual call for pastors to act as true shepherds by actively providing rest and restoration for God's people, as depicted in Psalm 23. It criticizes how the contemporary church often mirrors societal work addiction, inadvertently demanding more labor from congregants and contributing to burnout and church dropout rates instead of offering genuine sabbath. Therefore, the church must prioritize creating space for rest to truly care for its flock.

item.title: Why Not Saturday?
item.description: The Old Testament Sabbath, rooted in Israel's deliverance from Egyptian slavery, symbolized freedom from bondage, a principle Jesus demonstrated by healing on the Sabbath to liberate people from suffering. For Christians, this ultimate freedom was achieved through Christ's resurrection on Sunday, transforming the Sabbath into a mission to seek deliverance for all people from every form of spiritual and physical bondage.

item.title: Why Sunday?
item.description: Daily devotional for Nov 3, 2025
